titleCardParagraphs: Excel's SEQUENCE function: Generate list of sequential numbers.
This guide explains in depth how to replicate Excel's SEQUENCE functionality in Python using pandas and numpy.
We will cover syntax, multiple examples, edge cases, performance considerations, common mistakes, and best practices.

paragraphs: The SEQUENCE function in Excel allows users to generate list of sequential numbers.
Syntax and parameters are flexible, allowing for optional arguments and different modes of operation.
Excel formulas can be combined with other functions, making this versatile in reporting and analysis.

examplesTable.description: Another common example of SEQUENCE in practice.

introParagraphs: To mimic Excel's SEQUENCE in pandas, you can use several approaches depending on context.
Below are multiple strategies, each with pros and cons.
These code examples also illustrate performance differences and how to handle missing data.

codeSections.title: Basic usage in pandas
paragraphs: Simple equivalent of SEQUENCE using core pandas methods.
Useful for small datasets and straightforward logic.
codeLines: seq = np.arange(start, start + rows*cols*step, step)[:rows*cols].reshape(rows, cols)

codeSections.title: Alternative using numpy
paragraphs: For performance-sensitive tasks, numpy can be faster than pandas.
This approach is vectorized and avoids Python loops.

codeSections.title: Advanced usage
paragraphs: For complex business logic, combine pandas, numpy, and custom functions.
This is useful when porting long Excel formulas into maintainable Python code.
codeLines: import pandas as pd, numpy as np

introParagraphs: Here are common mistakes when replicating Excel logic in pandas:
These include indexing errors, type mismatches, handling NaN values, and misinterpreting Excel defaults.
We provide at least three examples for clarity.

codeSections.title: Type coercion issues
paragraphs: Excel coerces types differently than pandas.

codeSections.title: NA handling
paragraphs: Excel ignores blanks, pandas uses NaN.
codeLines: print(df['A'].fillna(0))  # Excel often treats blanks as 0 in some functions

codeSections.title: Performance assumptions
paragraphs: Excel is fine with small datasets, pandas/numpy scale better for large data.
